In res ipsa loquitur, the existence of the first three elements is inferred from the existence of injury that does not ordinarily occur without negligence.
story:
It was a sunny Saturday afternoon at the local golf course. Dr. Thompson, an accomplished golfer, had just had his morning round. Later that day, her friend, Sarah, decided to try out the driving range. While watching from the sidelines, Sarah witnessed an unusual accident. Rachel, a novice golfer, hit a golf ball, which landed behind a large net and wrapped its leash around a retired golfer's neck. The golfer stumbled, tripped, and fell on his elbow, injuring it severely.

Sarah approached Rachel, concerned, and inquired about her actions. Rachel explained that she had hit the ball, but denied intentionally aiming at the net or anyone. There were no witnesses to the incident or any dashcam to capture the ball's trajectory.

Rachel could claim the golf course is responsible, arguing the net should have been better positioned or secured since it caught the ball and caused the injury. Alternatively, the golf course could argue it wasn't their duty to prevent accidents with golf balls. However, the injury shouldn't have happened without someone's negligence being involved because the unusual event of a golf ball's leash getting tangled around a person's neck like it did points to neglect.

definition:
Res judicata or res iudicata, also known as claim preclusion, is the Latin term for judged matter, and refers to either of two concepts in common law civil procedure: a case in which there has been a final judgment and that is no longer subject to appeal; and the legal doctrine meant to bar (or preclude) relitigation of a claim between the same parties.
In the case of res judicata, the matter cannot be raised again, either in the same court or in a different court. A court will use res judicata to deny reconsideration of a matter. The doctrine of res judicata is a method of preventing injustice to the parties of a case supposedly finished but perhaps also or mostly a way of avoiding unnecessary waste of judicial resources. Res judicata does not merely prevent future judgments from contradicting earlier ones, but also prevents litigants from multiplying judgments.
It is similar to the concept of double jeopardy and non bis in idem in criminal law, but the protection in criminal prosecutions only bars an identical prosecution for the same offense. However, a different offense may be charged on identical evidence at a second trial; whereas, res judicata precludes any causes of action or claims that may arise from the previously litigated subject matter.
story:
Sarah and Mike had a contentious relationship that ended after they reached a settlement agreement, which was approved by the court, three years ago. As part of the agreement, Sarah received a significant amount of alimony and shared custody of their young daughter.

Fast forward to today, Mike has fallen on hard times and is struggling to make ends meet. He is now insisting that Sarah, who has also experienced financial difficulties, should pay more in alimony to help him cover his expenses. Sarah is understandably upset and argues that the original agreement she and Mike signed was fair and should stand.

In court, Sarah's lawyer argues that the matter is res judicata, citing the final judgment and settlement agreement from three years ago. The judge agrees, citing the doctrine of res judicata, and rules that the matter is not open for further litigation. Mike's new claims are essentially a rehashing of the same issues that were already decided in the original case.

The judge explains that the concept of res judicata prevents the two parties from relitigating the same matter, even if circumstances have changed. Mike and Sarah agreed to the original settlement and it is now final. The court will not revisit the matter, even if Mike is now in a more difficult financial situation. The doctrine of res judicata ensures that the parties move on, rather than engaging in endless litigation.

definition:
In the USA, the rescue doctrine of the law of torts holds that if a tortfeasor creates a circumstance that places the tort victim in danger, the tortfeasor is liable not only for the harm caused to the victim, but also the harm caused to any person injured in an effort to rescue that victim. This doctrine was originally promulgated by Benjamin N. Cardozo in the 1921 case, Wagner v. Int'l Ry. Co. There, writing for the Court of Appeals of New York (which is the supreme court of that state), Cardozo stated: "Danger invites rescue.  The cry of distress is the summons to relief [...] The emergency begets the man.  The wrongdoer may not have foreseen the coming of a deliverer.  He is accountable as if he had." The rescue doctrine was established nineteen years later, in the landmark case of Cote v. Palmer.
Essentially, the rescue doctrine means that the rescuer can recover damages from a defendant when the rescuer is injured rescuing someone.  The defendant is usually negligent in causing the accident to occur.  Other cases have occurred where the plaintiff is injured rescuing the defendant and is able to collect damages. 
In Wagner v. International Railway, riders on the defendant's trains were allowed to walk between cars while the train was moving.  In one incident, a rider fell through the cars.  The plaintiff, trying to help the fallen rider, was injured himself.  The court found the defendant liable because of negligence to allow riders to walk between cars while the train was moving. The aforementioned example is a reference to the concept that Danger invites Rescue. Whoever caused the accident will be liable for any subsequent accident which develops as a result of the original accident. 
Essentially, in its pure form the Rescue Doctrine boils down to 4 main elements - all of which must be met in order to bring it to bear for the person asserting its privilege.

There must be peril or the appearance of peril to a third party, caused by the defendant.
That peril or appearance of peril must be imminent
A reasonable person would recognize the peril or appearance of peril and the plaintiff must also have actually recognized it.
The plaintiff must have exercised reasonable care in effecting the rescue.
story:
Sarah was driving home from work on a rainy evening when she saw a car submerged in a flooded ditch on the side of the road. The driver, unable to open his door, was frantically banging on the window, waving for help.

Feeling sympathy for the stranded driver, Sarah pulled over and got out of her car to assist him. As she waded into the water to try and open the door, she slipped and fell, injuring her ankle.

The driver, whose name was John, was shaken but unharmed. He had been speeding around a curve and lost control of his vehicle, leading to the accident.

Sarah filed a lawsuit against John, citing the Rescue doctrine. She argued that John's negligence in driving recklessly had created the situation that put her in danger, and that she was trying to rescue him when she was injured.

The court agreed, ruling that John was liable for the harm caused to Sarah. The judge noted that the peril or appearance of peril was imminent, as the driver was trapped in the car and struggling to free himself. A reasonable person would recognize the danger and, like Sarah, feel compelled to act to rescue the stranded driver.

Furthermore, the court found that Sarah had exercised reasonable care in effecting the rescue, as she had taken the necessary precautions to try and help John despite the dangerous conditions.

In the end, Sarah recovered damages for her injuries, and John was held accountable for the harm caused by his negligence. The Rescue doctrine applied, as the court concluded that John's initial wrongdoing had led to the subsequent harm caused to Sarah while she was trying to rescue him.

definition:
Respondeat superior (Latin:  "let the master answer"; plural:  respondeant superiores) is a doctrine that a party is responsible for (and has vicarious liability for) acts of his agents.: 794  For example, in the United States, there are circumstances when an employer is liable for acts of employees performed within the course of their employment.  This rule is also called the master-servant rule, recognized in both common law and civil law jurisdictions.
In a broader scope, respondeat superior is based upon the concept of vicarious liability.
story:
Here is a short story illustrating the concept of Respondeat Superior:

Emily worked as a customer service representative at a large retail store, Smith's Electronics. She was responsible for responding to customer complaints and resolving issues related to returns and exchanges. While at a store branch located in another city for a training session, Emily became upset with a customer who was pushing her for a refund for a damaged product. Frustrated with the customer, Emily lashed out, yelling at the customer and eventually reduced the refund to a significantly smaller amount.

The customer complained to the store's corporate office, who immediately launched an investigation into the incident. During the investigation, Emily revealed that she had been following the same procedure for handling returns that had been instructed by her supervisor at the training session. It was, however, acknowledged that the procedure had been wildly invalidly applied in this one case, resulting in discrimination.

Smith's Electronics corporation took swift action, not only to resolve the complaint with the customer but also to apologize, rectify its policies, and fire the manager who had given the training, and applied severe disciplinary actions against Emily, holding her responsible for her behavior toward the customer. Jong, the corporation's customer service manager, stated, 'employees who act in the scope of their employment don't act alone, their actions are reflective of the organization.'

definition:
Restitution and unjust enrichment is the field of law relating to gains-based recovery. In contrast with damages (the law of compensation), restitution is a claim or remedy requiring a defendant to give up benefits wrongfully obtained. Liability for restitution is primarily governed by the "principle of unjust enrichment": A person who has been unjustly enriched at the expense of another is required to make restitution.
This principle derives from late Roman law, as stated in the Latin maxim attributed to Sextus Pomponius, Jure naturae aequum est neminem cum alterius detrimentum et injuria fieri locupletiorem ("By natural law it is just that no one should be enriched by another's loss or injury"). In civil law systems, it is also referred to as enrichment without cause or unjustified enrichment.
In pre-modern English common law, restitutionary claims were often brought in an action for assumpsit and later in a claim for money had and received. The seminal case giving a general theory for when restitution would be available is Lord Mansfield's decision in Moses v Macferlan (1760), which imported into the common law notions of conscience from English chancery. Blackstone's Commentaries also endorsed this approach, citing Moses.
Where an individual is unjustly enriched, modern common law imposes an obligation upon the recipient to make restitution, subject to defences such as change of position and the protection of bona fide purchasers from contrary equitable title. Liability for an unjust enrichment arises irrespective of wrongdoing on the part of the recipient, though it may affect available remedies. And restitution can also be ordered for wrongs (also called "waiver of tort" because election of remedies historically occurred when first filing a suit). This may be treated as a distinct basis for restitution, or it may be treated as a subset of unjust enrichment.
Unjust enrichment is not to be confused with illicit enrichment, which is a legal concept referring to the enjoyment of an amount of wealth by a person that is not justified by reference to their lawful income.
story:
As the sun set over the quiet town of Willow Creek, 35-year-old Emma couldn't help but feel a mix of emotions. She had recently discovered that her former business partner, James, had secretly sold their jointly-owned company to a large corporation, without her knowledge or consent.

The irony wasn't lost on Emma - the company they had built from scratch was now worth millions, thanks largely to her innovative ideas and tireless efforts. Yet, she was left out of the deal and had lost her job in the process.

As she pondered her next move, Emma recalled a phrase she had learned in law school: "Unjust Enrichment." She had always thought it was just a fancy legal term, but now it seemed to be her only hope.

Unjust Enrichment, or as the Romans would have it, "Jure naturae aequum est neminem cum alterius detrimentum et injuria fieri locupletiorem", meant that whoever had gained an unjust benefit at another's expense should make restitution. It was a concept that resonated deeply with Emma, as she realized that James had clearly gained from her own toil and sweat.

With her mind made up, Emma decided to take James to court, seeking restitution for the unjust benefits he had derived from their partnership. The case would be fought on the basis of unjust enrichment, rather than through breach of contract or tort. Emma's goal was to reclaim her rightful share of the company's value, using the principle of unjust enrichment to ensure that James couldn't keep her hard-earned gains. As she walked out of the courthouse, Emma felt a sense of determination wash over her. She knew that justice would be served, and that James would be forced to relinquish his ill-gotten gains.

definition: The reverse doctrine of equivalents is a legal doctrine of United States patent law, according to which a device that appears to literally infringe a patent claim, by including elements or limitations that correspond to each element or limitation of the patent claim, nonetheless does not infringe the patent, because the accused device operates on a different principle. That is, "it performs the same or a similar function in a substantially different way." It has been said that "the purpose of the 'reverse' doctrine is to prevent unwarranted extension of the claims beyond a fair scope of the patentee's invention."
story:
Meet Emma, a talented chef who invented a revolutionary new way to cook perfect eggs. Her patent claim describes a kitchen device that uses a combination of microwave radiation and gentle air circulation to cook eggs precisely to any desired level of doneness. The claim specifies that the device must use microwaves to heat the eggs, and that the air circulation must be designed to prevent hotspots and ensure even cooking.

Years later, a rival chef, Michael, develops a competing egg-cooking device. Michael's device uses high-frequency sound waves to vibrate the eggs, causing them to cook quickly and evenly. While Michael's device appears to literally infringe Emma's patent claim, as it uses a combination of elements similar to those described in the patent claim (a means of heating and a means of air circulation), the competition's device operates on a different principle.

In court, Emma argues that Michael's device infringes her patent because it performs the same function as her device (cooking eggs perfectly). However, the judge finds that the reverse doctrine of equivalents applies. Although Michael's device includes elements similar to those described in the patent claim, it operates on a fundamentally different principle (using sound waves instead of microwaves). The judge rules that Emma's patent is not infringed, as Michael's device does not fall within the fair scope of the patentee's invention.

definition:
Rights are legal, social, or ethical principles of freedom or entitlement; that is, rights are the fundamental normative rules about what is allowed of people or owed to people according to some legal system, social convention, or ethical theory. Rights are an important concept in law and ethics, especially theories of justice and deontology.
The history of social conflicts has often involved attempts to define and redefine rights. According to the Stanford Encyclopedia of Philosophy, "rights structure the form of governments, the content of laws, and the shape of morality as it is currently perceived".
story:
Sarah was a single mother working two jobs to provide for her 7-year-old son, Max. She was tired, but determined to give him the best life possible. One day, she received an eviction notice from her landlord, citing a technicality in the lease agreement.

Sarah was devastated. Where would she and Max go? She couldn't afford a new place, and Max loved their current home, with its small backyard where he could play. She remembered a conversation with her friend, Emma, who was an advocate for tenants' rights. Emma had told Sarah that tenants had the right to privacy, and that the landlord couldn't simply evict them without just cause.

Sarah stood firm, refusing to leave her home without a fight. She contacted the local tenant advocacy group and they helped her gather evidence to dispute the eviction. The day of the court hearing arrived, and Sarah felt nervous but determined. The judge ruled in her favor, citing the tenant's right to privacy and the landlord's failure to provide adequate notice.

As Sarah and Max walked out of the courtroom, victorious, Sarah realized that rights were not just abstract concepts, but real, tangible powers that could protect people like her from exploitation. She felt empowered, knowing that she had asserted her right to a safe and stable home for her son. The experience taught her that rights were not just a abstract idea, but a living, breathing force that could make a real difference in people's lives.

definition:
In United States law, ripeness refers to the readiness of a case for litigation; "a claim is not ripe for adjudication if it rests upon contingent future events that may not occur as anticipated, or indeed may not occur at all." For example, if a law of ambiguous quality has been enacted but never applied, a case challenging that law lacks the ripeness necessary for a decision.
The goal is to prevent premature adjudication; if a dispute is insufficiently developed, any potential injury or stake is too speculative to warrant judicial action. Ripeness issues most usually arise when a plaintiff seeks anticipatory relief, such as an injunction. 
Originally stated in Liverpool, New York & Philadelphia Steamship Co. v. Commissioners of Emigration (1885), ripeness is one the seven rules of the constitutional avoidance doctrine established in Ashwander v. Tennessee Valley Authority (1936) that requires that the Supreme Court of the United States to "not 'anticipate a question of constitutional law in advance of the necessity of deciding it.'" The Court fashioned a two-part test for assessing ripeness challenges to federal regulations. The case is often applied to constitutional challenges to federal and state statutes as well. The Court said in Abbott Laboratories v. Gardner, 387 U.S. 136 (1967):

Without undertaking to survey the intricacies of the ripeness doctrine it is fair to say that its basic rationale is to prevent the courts, through avoidance of premature adjudication, from entangling themselves in abstract disagreements over administrative policies, and also to protect the agencies from judicial interference until an administrative decision has been formalized and its effects felt in a concrete way by the challenging parties. The problem is best seen in a twofold aspect, requiring us to evaluate both the fitness of the issues for judicial decision and the hardship to the parties of withholding court consideration.
In both Abbott Laboratories and its first companion case, Toilet Goods Association v. Gardner, 387 U.S. 158 (1967), the Court upheld pre-enforcement review of an administrative regulation. However, the Court denied such review in the second companion case because any harm from noncompliance with the FDA regulation at issue was too speculative in the Court's opinion to justify judicial review. Justice Harlan wrote for the Court in all three cases.
The ripeness doctrine should not be confused with the advisory opinion doctrine, another justiciability concept in American law.
story:
Meet Emily, a landscape architect who owns a small design firm. She's been following the development of a new municipal ordinance designed to reduce stormwater runoff in her city. The ordinance requires property owners to install rain gardens on their properties to absorb excess water.

Emily is concerned that the ordinance will increase her design costs and potentially impact her business. She decides to challenge the ordinance in court, seeking a declaration that it's unconstitutional and an injunction to stop its implementation.

However, the ordinance has just been passed and no property owner has been notified that they must install a rain garden. The ordinance hasn't been applied yet, and there's no concrete harm to Emily or her business.

As Emily's lawyer prepares to file a lawsuit, they face a ripeness challenge from the city. The city argues that Emily's claim is not ripe for adjudication because the ordinance hasn't been enforced and any potential harm to Emily's business is speculative.

Emily's lawyer agrees that the court should not preview or second-guess the ordinance at this stage. Instead, they suggest that Emily wait until the city begins enforcing the ordinance and she actually faces a specific problem, such as receiving a notice to install a rain garden or being fined for noncompliance.

In this scenario, the court would likely hold that Emily's claim lacks ripeness and dismiss the case. Emily's lawyer advises her to focus on developing the issue by encouraging the city to enforce the ordinance and then seeking judicial review once the ordinance's effects are felt in a concrete way.

definition: The rule according to a higher law is a philosophical concept that no law may be enforced by the government unless it conforms with certain universal principles (written or unwritten) of fairness, morality, and justice. Thus, the rule according to a higher law may serve as a practical legal criterion to qualify the instances of political or economical decision-making, when a government, even though acting in conformity with clearly defined and properly enacted law, still produces results which many observers find unfair or unjust.
story:
The small town of Willow Creek was known for its idyllic summer festivals, attracting visitors from all over the country. However, the town council, eager to boost revenue, passed a law requiring all vendors to pay a hefty fee for a permit to sell food at the festivals.

Maria, a young single mother, had been running a popular homemade ice cream cart at the festivals for years, relying on the income to support her family. But with the new law, she wouldn't be able to afford the permit fee, which would put her out of business. She felt that the law unfairly targeted small, family-owned vendors like hers.

Meanwhile, a large corporation, Sweet Delights, Inc., was poised to take over the festival food scene by buying permits for multiple vendors. They didn't need to worry about the permit fee, as they could easily absorb it into their profits.

As the festival season approached, Maria and her fellow small vendors felt forced to close up shop. The townspeople, who had grown attached to Maria's homemade ice cream, were upset and argued that the law was unfair and unjust. Despite being a "legally" enacted law, the town council was faced with a moral dilemma: was it right to allow a large corporation to monopolize the festival food scene while small, family-owned businesses like Maria's went under?

The rule according to higher law suggested that no law can be enforced if it goes against universal principles of fairness and justice. In this case, the law would need to be reevaluated, taking into account the impact on small businesses and the community, to ensure that everyone is treated fairly and justly.

definition:
The rule against foreign revenue enforcement, often abbreviated to the revenue rule, is a general legal principle that the courts of one country will not enforce the tax laws of another country.  The rule is part of the conflict of laws rules developed at common law, and forms part of the act of state doctrine.
In State of Colorado v. Harbeck, 133 N.E. 357, 360 (N.Y. 1921) the court referred to

The ... well-settled  principle  of  private international law which precludes one state from acting as a collector of taxes for a sister state and from enforcing its penal or revenue laws as such. The rule is universally recognized that the revenue laws of one state have no force in another.
In England, Lord Denning MR said in Att-Gen of New Zealand v Ortiz [1984] AC 1 at 20: 

No one has ever doubted that our courts will not entertain a suit brought by a foreign sovereign, directly or indirectly, to enforce the penal or revenue laws of that foreign state.  We do not sit to collect taxes for another country or to inflict punishments for it.
The rule has been repeatedly applied in the United Kingdom, the United States, Canada, Australia, Ireland, Singapore, and other countries.  It has also been codified into statute in various countries.
story:
Maria, a Spanish national, had inherited a property in the United States from her uncle. When she decided to sell the property, she found out that she owed back taxes to the Spanish government. To recover the debt, the Spanish tax authority, Hacienda, demanded that Maria transfer the funds from her US bank account directly to their account.

Maria, feeling bullied, consulted with her US-based financial advisor, who advised her to ignore the demand. He explained that the Rule against Foreign Revenue Enforcement would prevent the US courts from enforcing the Spanish tax laws on US soil.

After some contemplation, Maria decided to follow her advisor's advice. When Hacienda sent her a notice threatening to freeze her US bank account, Maria's advisor contested the notice, citing the revenue rule. The case eventually made its way to court, where the judge ruled in Maria's favor, stating that the US courts would not enforce the Spanish tax laws in this situation.

The court's decision allowed Maria to keep her US bank account intact and avoid any direct involvement with the Spanish tax authority. Maria was relieved and grateful that the Rule against Foreign Revenue Enforcement protected her from the encroachment of foreign taxation.

In the end, Maria's decision to seek legal advice and cite the revenue rule saved her from a potential financial nightmare. The story illustrates the legal principle that the courts of one country will not enforce the tax laws of another country, protecting individuals like Maria from unnecessary interference and ensuring the integrity of domestic tax systems.

definition:
Rylands v Fletcher (1868) LR 3 HL 330 is a leading decision by the House of Lords which established a new area of English tort law.  It established the rule that one's non-natural use of their land, which leads to another's land being damaged as a result of dangerous things emanating from the land, is strictly liable.
Rylands employed contractors to build a reservoir on his land. As a result of negligent work done, the reservoir burst and flooded a neighbouring mine, run by Fletcher, causing £937 worth of damage (equivalent to £111,200 in 2023). Fletcher brought a claim under negligence against Rylands. At the court of first instance, the majority ruled in favour of Rylands. Baron Bramwell, dissenting, argued that the claimant had the right to enjoy his land free of interference from water, and that Rylands was guilty of trespass and the commissioning of a nuisance. Bramwell's argument was affirmed by the Court of Exchequer Chamber and the House of Lords, leading to the development of the "Rule in Rylands v Fletcher". 
This doctrine was further developed by English courts, and made an immediate impact on the law. Prior to Rylands, English courts had not based their decisions in similar cases on strict liability, and had focused on the intention behind the actions rather than the nature of the actions themselves. In contrast, Rylands imposed strict liability on those found detrimental in such a fashion without having to prove a duty of care or negligence, which brought the law into line with that relating to public reservoirs and marked a significant doctrinal shift.  The rule in Rylands has both been distinguished with and regarded as a species of the tort of private nuisance and even construed as a "liability rule". Unlike ordinary cases of private nuisance, the rule in Rylands requires the escape of a thing that arises from a non-natural use rather than the typical interference emanating from unreasonable use of land. It additionally does not require an act to be continuous, which is typically a requirement for nuisance. Academics have criticised the rule both for the economic damage such a doctrine could cause and for its limited applicability. 
The tort of Rylands v Fletcher has been disclaimed in various jurisdictions, including Scotland, where it was described as "a heresy that ought to be extirpated", and Australia, where the High Court chose to destroy the doctrine in Burnie Port Authority v General Jones Pty Ltd. Within England and Wales, however, Rylands remains valid law, although the decisions in Cambridge Water Co Ltd v Eastern Counties Leather plc and Transco plc v Stockport Metropolitan Borough Council make it clear that it is no longer an independent tort, but instead a sub-tort of nuisance.
story:
"The Great River Run-In"

It was a sunny Saturday afternoon when Emma decided to organize a family picnic by the riverbank. Her neighbors, the Smiths, had been using their land to cultivate a beautiful orchard for years, but recently, they had started to build a large dam to create a private reservoir to supply water to their farm.

As the picnic was in full swing, Emma noticed the dam started to leak, causing water to overflow and flood the riverbank. The rushing water swept away the picnic blankets, food, and drinks, and even knocked over the family's small boat, rendering it unrepairable.

The Smiths claimed they had taken all necessary precautions and had warned the authorities about the dam's construction. However, Emma was not convinced and decided to seek compensation for the damage caused to her family's property and belongings.

In court, Emma's lawyers argued that the Smiths' non-natural use of their land (building the dam) had led to a danger that escaped and damaged her property. The judge agreed, ruling that the Smiths were strictly liable for the damages, citing the Rule in Rylands v Fletcher. This meant that the Smiths were accountable for the damage because of their non-natural use of their land, without needing to prove they had acted negligently or with intent to harm.

The Smiths were ordered to pay Emma a significant amount of compensation for the damage caused. While they had built the dam to benefit their farm, they had also put others at risk. This example illustrates the strict liability principle in Rylands v Fletcher, where the non-natural use of land can lead to severe consequences, and the landowner is accountable for the damages that result.

definition:
A safe harbor is a provision of a statute or a regulation that specifies that certain conduct will be deemed not to violate a given rule.  It is usually found in connection with a more-vague, overall standard.  By contrast, "unsafe harbors" describe conduct that will be deemed to violate the rule.
For example, in the context of a statute that requires drivers to "not drive recklessly", a clause specifying that "driving under 25 miles per hour will be conclusively deemed not to constitute reckless driving" is a "safe harbor".  Likewise, a clause saying that "driving over 90 miles per hour will be conclusively deemed to constitute reckless driving" would be an "unsafe harbor".  In this example, driving between 25 miles per hour and 90 miles per hour would fall outside of either a safe harbor or an unsafe harbor, and would thus be left to be judged according to the vague "reckless" standard.
story:
Emily was a young professional who liked to walk her dog, Max, after work. One evening, while on her daily stroll, Emily spotted a massive storm cloud gathering above. She had just received a notification from her employer that there was no designated parking available at the office the next day, so she decided to take a slightly more direct route home that avoided the main roads.

As she walked, the rain started pouring down, and she quickened her pace. Her phone rang; it was her boss, reminding her about the morning's urgent meeting and asking her to be on time. Emily was already soaking wet, but she picked up the pace even more to get a head start on the traffic.

In her hurry, Emily's support boot slipped on a loose paving stone, causing her to miss a step and lose her balance. Thankfully, a nearby bystander caught her and prevented her from falling into the storm drain. Shaken, Emily took a few moments to collect herself before continuing home.

Later that evening, as Emily reflected on her afternoon, she wondered whether she had been reckless. Technically, the regulations required drivers to be "prudent when walking on uneven terrain in a rainstorm." But Emily didn't recall reading anything in the regulations about what speed was speediest – be too slow, or too fast.

definition:
A scène à faire (French for "scene to be made" or "scene that must be done"; plural:  scènes à faire; both pronounced [sɛn a fɛʁ]) is a scene in a work of fiction which is almost obligatory for a work in that genre.
In the United States, it also refers to a principle in copyright law in which certain elements of a creative work are held to be not protected when they are mandated by or customary to the genre, a principle which has been expanded to cover other fields such as software development.
story:
As a struggling author, Sarah had always dreamed of writing the next great mystery novel. She poured her heart and soul into her manuscript, crafting intricate plots and witty dialogue. But as she shopped her work around to publishers, she began to notice a trend. Editors would compliment her writing, but ultimately reject her work, saying "this is a great take on the genre, but we've seen this before."

Sarah didn't understand. Her story was original, wasn't it? Yet, as she delved deeper into the mystery genre, she began to realize that certain tropes and conventions were simply expected. The hard-boiled detective, the femme fatale, the sinister plot twist – these were all staples of the genre. And as much as Sarah wove them into her story, they were also the reason her work was being rejected.

It dawned on her that she was unknowingly bound by the principle of "scenes à faire". She was creating the very scenes that readers expected to see in a mystery novel, but in doing so, she was also leaving her work open to criticism that it was unoriginal. In the end, Sarah decided to take a risk and mix things up. She created a unique protagonist, one who defied genres and conventions. And while her work was still rejected, this time, it was because it was too different, too bold, and not zany enough.

This experience taught Sarah that in order to stand out, she had to be willing to defy the crowd, to take risks, and to push the boundaries of what was expected. And in doing so, she discovered that the true scene à faire was the one where she took her writing to bold new places, where she pioneered a new wave of storytelling, and where she refused to be bound by the limitations of genre. The rest, as they say, is history.

definition:
A clerical error is an error on the part of an office worker, often a secretary or personal assistant. The phrase may also be used as an excuse to deflect blame away from specific individuals, such as high-powered executives, and instead redirect it to the more anonymous clerical staff.
A clerical error in a legal document is called a scrivener's error.
story:
Here's a story that illustrates the legal concept of a Scrivener's error:

Meet Emily, a busy paralegal working for a law firm. She is tasked with drafting a contract between two companies, ABC Inc. and XYZ Corp. Emily is meticulous and double-checks her work, but in her haste to meet the deadline, she accidentally types the wrong contact information for one of the parties on the second page of the contract.

The contract is signed and executed, but several months later, ABC Inc. claims that XYZ Corp. failed to meet a critical deadline because they never received the notice, which was incorrectly addressed. XYZ Corp. responds that the notice was never delivered, as the contact information was incorrect.

Emily is asked to review the contract to determine what went wrong. Upon reviewing the document, she realizes that she made the error, typing the wrong phone number and email address on page 2. Despite her best efforts, the mistake slipped through the cracks.

This scenario illustrates a Scrivener's error, a clerical mistake made by a professional who is responsible for drafting and preparing legal documents, allowing the courts to potentially unwind the consequences of the error if it can be proven that the mistake was unintended and not malicious. In this case, the courts may decide that the contract is voidable due to the Scrivener's error, which could affect the rights and obligations of all parties involved.

definition:
In a slippery slope argument, a course of action is rejected because the slippery slope advocate believes it will lead to a chain reaction resulting in an undesirable end or ends. The core of the slippery slope argument is that a specific decision under debate is likely to result in unintended consequences. The strength of such an argument depends on whether the small step really is likely to lead to the effect. This is quantified in terms of what is known as the warrant (in this case, a demonstration of the process that leads to the significant effect).
This type of argument is sometimes used as a form of fearmongering in which the probable consequences of a given action are exaggerated in an attempt to scare the audience. When the initial step is not demonstrably likely to result in the claimed effects, this is called the slippery slope fallacy. This is a type of informal fallacy, and is a subset of continuum fallacy, in that it ignores the possibility of middle ground and assumes a discrete transition from category A to category B. Other idioms for the slippery slope fallacy are the thin edge of the wedge, domino fallacy (as a form of domino effect argument) or dam burst, and various other terms that are sometimes considered distinct argument types or reasoning flaws, such as the camel's nose in the tent, parade of horribles, boiling frog, and snowball effect.
story:
The small town of Oakdale was facing a dilemma. The local government was considering a proposal to allow one small marijuana dispensary to operate within the town limits. The proponents argued that it would bring in much-needed tax revenue and create jobs, while the opponents claimed it would lead to widespread drug use and crime.

Sarah, a concerned citizen, was worried about the implications of allowing marijuana sales. She believed that once the town allowed one dispensary, it would be a slippery slope, leading to more and more dispensaries opening up throughout the town. She argued that before long, Oakdale would become a hub for drug trafficking and the town's reputation would be tarnished.

At first, the town council was skeptical of Sarah's concerns, but she presented a persuasive argument. She pointed out that other cities that had initially allowed small amounts of marijuana had eventually found themselves overwhelmed by the demand and the proliferation of illegal activity. She warned that if Oakdale didn't draw the line at just one dispensary, it would be like "adding water to a sinking ship." The more dispensaries that opened, the more it would become a magnet for drug traffickers and users.

The town council took Sarah's concerns seriously and ultimately decided to reject the proposal, citing the potential for a slippery slope. Although some residents were upset by the decision, most agreed that better to err on the side of caution and protect the town's integrity.

In this scenario, Sarah's argument about the slippery slope demonstrates how a single action can lead to a chain reaction of unforeseen consequences. While it's impossible to predict the exact outcome, her warning about the potential harm was enough to sway the town council's decision.

doctrine: Murders of Haile Kifer and Nicholas Brady
definition:
The murders of Haile Kifer and Nicholas Brady occurred on Thanksgiving Day of 2012, when Haile Kifer, 18, and her cousin, Nicholas Brady, 17, broke into the home of 64-year-old Byron David Smith in Little Falls, Minnesota, in the United States. Smith shot the teens separately and 10 minutes apart as they entered the basement where he was, later stating to police he was worried about them being armed. After already shooting them once, he repeatedly taunted them while they were injured as he shot them both in an execution style until they were dead. He did not report that he had killed Kifer and Brady until the day after the murders, keeping their corpses in his closet. On April 29, 2014, he was found guilty of two counts of premeditated first-degree murder. He was sentenced to life in prison without the possibility of parole.
The case sparked debate over the "castle doctrine", which allows homeowners to defend their homes with lethal force. The prosecution alleged that Smith's actions and a recording he made himself while the incidents were unfolding showed premeditation (lying in wait) and that he used excessive force after having neutralized the threat. He was convicted by a jury after three hours of deliberation and sentenced to life in prison.
story:
As the sun set on their quiet suburban neighborhood, the Smiths were preparing for their annual Thanksgiving dinner. Meanwhile, 19-year-old Alex and his friend, 17-year-old Jake, hatched a plan to break into the Smith's house in search of valuables.

Under the cover of darkness, Alex and Jake crept onto the property, trying not to make a sound. They spotted a window that was slightly ajar and decided to make their entry. Unbeknownst to them, Mr. Smith, who was sitting in the basement, had been alerted to their presence by a noise-making device.

As they made their way down to the basement, Alex stopped to adjust his backpack, unaware that Mr. Smith was waiting in the darkness. Suddenly, a shot rang out, and Alex fell to the ground. Terrified, Jake froze, holding his breath as Mr. Smith approached him, gun still in hand.

"I should have killed you when you were on the floor," Mr. Smith growled, pressing the gun to Jake's temple. "You're lucky I chose to spare your life... for now." Jake collapsed onto the floor, and Mr. Smith left him there, only to return and finish him off with a hollow-point bullet to the head.

This tragic event highlights the legal concept of premeditated murder. As the prosecution argued, Mr. Smith did not act in genuine self-defense, but instead, searched for, and used excessive force against the intruders.

definition:
The spider in the web doctrine is a legal doctrine in Dutch patent law governing cross-border injunctions in patent infringement cases.  Under this doctrine, the Dutch courts would assume jurisdiction only in cases where the main defendant (the "spider") was located in the Netherlands and where the other defendants were part of a group of companies and acted based on a common business policy of this group (the "web"), regardless of the nation in which the disputed patent was issued.
Decisions by the European Court of Justice (ECJ) have cast some doubt on the continuing validity of this doctrine.  This is due in part to the fact that the ECJ did not feel that Dutch courts were competent to make predictions or judgments about the validity of patents granted outside the Netherlands, preferring to grant jurisdiction to the countries in which the patent was granted.
story:
Meet Emma, a brilliant entrepreneur who invented a revolutionary new smartwatch in her garage in Amsterdam. She patented her design and founded "TechCorp", a company that would manufacture and distribute her product worldwide. TechCorp has subsidiaries in many countries, including Germany, the UK, and the US.

As TechCorp's product gains popularity, Emma notices that a competitor, "SmartWatches Inc." based in California, is copying her design and selling similar smartwatches worldwide. Emma decides to take legal action against SmartWatches Inc. and its subsidiaries in Europe.

In the Netherlands, the Dutch court is asked to issue an injunction against SmartWatches Inc. and its European subsidiaries, claiming they are part of a common "web" controlled by the California-based company. The Dutch court applies the "Spider in the Web" doctrine and assumes jurisdiction, reasoning that since TechCorp's main defendant (the "spider") is located in the Netherlands, and the European subsidiaries are part of the same web, they should also be subject to the Dutch court's jurisdiction.

However, the European Court of Justice (ECJ) later casts doubt on this doctrine, stating that Dutch courts should not assume jurisdiction over patents granted outside the Netherlands. The ECJ prefers to grant jurisdiction to the countries where the patent was granted, in this case, the US.

As a result, the case is re-filed in the US, and SmartWatches Inc. is brought to justice for infringing on Emma's patent. Emma ultimately wins her case, but the expansion of the lawsuit is delayed and more complicated due to the conflicting jurisdictional decisions.

definition: Spring and Autumn Courts (春秋决狱) were an ancient Chinese judicial system, in which judges judge how to convict a case based on the ideas of righteousness of the Spring and Autumn Annals. The Spring and Autumn Courts began in the reign of Emperor Wu of Han and continued until the Tang dynasty when Confucianism and Jurisprudence merged to create the "unity of ritual and law".
story:
During the Han dynasty, a dispute arose between two neighboring villages, Wetang and Shangfang. The villagers of Wetang accused the villagers of Shangfang of stealing their precious rice harvest. The parties involved brought their case to the Imperial Court, seeking justice.

The judges assigned to the case, known as the Spring and Autumn Courts, gathered the evidence and witnesses. They pored over the ancient texts of the Spring and Autumn Annals, seeking guidance on how to render a just verdict.

As they deliberated, one judge, Master Zhou, suggested that the stealing of rice was a violation of the principles of righteousness. "Is it not wrong for one village to take from another what is not theirs?" he asked. Another judge, Master Li, countered that perhaps the stealing was not as clear-cut as it seemed. "Were the villagers of Shangfang perhaps forced to take the rice due to famine or drought?" he posited.

After careful consideration, the judges decided that the villagers of Shangfang had indeed acted unjustly, but that they had done so out of desperation rather than malice. They ruled that the villagers of Wetang should forgive the offense and that the village of Shangfang should work to replenish their own stores.

The judges' verdict was guided by the principles of the Spring and Autumn Annals, which emphasized the importance of compassion, fairness, and social harmony. The case was settled, and the villagers of both Wetang and Shangfang reconciled, grateful for the wise and compassionate judiciary.

definition: Staatenverbund  is a neologism for a system of multi-level governance in which states work more closely together than in a confederation but, unlike a federal state, retain their own sovereignty. The concept is used in Germany to describe the European Union but has no direct equivalent in other languages. In German jurisprudence, a Staatenverbund is a supranational institution that may exercise sovereign acts (laws, coin money, etc.) but may not independently fix areas where it may exercise this power.
story:
In the charming town of Heidelberg, the annual Wine Festival had become a beloved tradition. As the town's population continued to grow, the local authorities realized that, with the influx of new residents, came new challenges. Housing, infrastructure, and environmental concerns arose, which the town council struggled to tackle on its own.

One day, a delegation from neighboring towns, like Stuttgart and Frankfurt, approached Heidelberg's mayor. They proposed a collaboration to address these common issues, as they too faced similar difficulties. They suggested creating a shared entity, which they dubbed the "Rhein-Neckar Regional Assembly" (RNA).

The RNA would have the power to make collective decisions on matters affecting all participating towns, like transportation planning and waste management. However, each town would retain its sovereignty and could veto decisions that didn't align with its interests. The RNA would not have the authority to override individual town laws or finances.

The Heidelberg town council welcomed the idea, and the RNA was born. The mayor of Heidelberg, accompanied by his counterparts from Stuttgart and Frankfurt, signed a declaration outlining the RNA's powers and limitations. The RNA would allow the towns to work together more effectively, yet each would maintain control over its internal affairs.

As the Wine Festival approached, the towns showcased their collaborative achievements, from regional public transportation to joint environmental initiatives. The success of the RNA exemplified the concept of Staatenverbund: a supranational institution exercising limited sovereignty, yet enabling the participating towns to tackle common challenges while preserving their individual autonomy.

definition:
Stadtluft macht frei ("urban air makes you free"), or Stadtluft macht frei nach Jahr und Tag ("city air makes you free after a year and a day"), is a German saying describing a principle of law in the Middle Ages. The period of a year and a day was a conventional period widely employed in Europe to represent a significant amount of time.  
From the 11th century onwards, liberated serfs and other members of the Third Estate founded settlements alongside the old Roman or Germanic ones. It was customary law that a city resident was free after one year and one day. After this he could no longer be reclaimed by his employer and thus became bound to the city. Serfs could flee the feudal lands and gain freedom in this way, making cities a territory outside the feudal system to a certain extent. This created the conditions for revolts such as the Münster Rebellion.
With the Statutum in favorem principum ("Statute in Favor of the Princes"), this regulation of customary law was officially abolished for the Holy Roman Empire in 1231/32. According to the statute, cities under royal jurisdiction were forbidden to protect serfs originally owned by the regional princes or their vassals. The statute is an example of power devolving from Imperial authority to that of territorial magnates during the drawn-out contest between the Hohenstaufen emperors and the Papacy.
The medieval concept of liberty was largely confined to traditional collective rights and privileges based in custom and precedent and often expressed in territorial liberties such as, to take English examples, the Liberties of the Tower of London or the Liberties of the Savoy. Historically, the development of individualism is a product of the ideology of liberalism, whose emphasis on modern individual liberties and freedom emerged in opposition to authoritarian oppression, in England culminating in the Glorious Revolution of 1688, and in France surfacing during the French Revolution.
story:
In the small village of Ravenswood, farmland worker Hans spent his days toiling under the control of the local lord, Sir Edward. Hans was bound to the land through a centuries-old feudal contract, leaving him little freedom to make his own choices. One day, Hans had had enough. He packed a small bag and set off towards the nearby city of Ashwood, hoping to escape his life of servitude.

After weeks of traveling, Hans finally arrived in Ashwood, exhausted but determined. He settled into a small cottage near the city gates, where he found work as a blacksmith's apprentice. As months passed, Hans grew to love his new life in the city. He made friends with fellow craftsmen, learned new skills, and even started his own business.

Exactly one year and one day after his arrival, Hans celebrated his newfound freedom. No longer could Sir Edward reclaim him as his serf, and Hans was now free to live his life as he chose. He was not bound to the land or a lord, but to the city and its people.

As Hans raised a cup of ale to his new freedom, he smiled, knowing that the "city air" had indeed set him free. He was no longer just a serf, but a citizen of Ashwood, with all the rights and privileges that came with it. And though Sir Edward may have lost his control over Hans, the city had welcomed him with open arms, granting him a chance to build a life of his own.

definition:
A stand-your-ground law, sometimes called a "line in the sand" or "no duty to retreat" law, provides that people may use deadly force when they reasonably believe it to be necessary to defend against certain violent crimes (right of self-defense). Under such a law, people have no duty to retreat before using deadly force in self-defense, so long as they are in a place where they are lawfully present. The exact details vary by jurisdiction.
The alternative to stand your ground is "duty to retreat". In jurisdictions that implement a duty to retreat, even a person who is unlawfully attacked (or who is defending someone who is unlawfully attacked) may not use deadly force if it is possible to instead avoid the danger with complete safety by retreating.
Even areas that impose a duty to retreat generally follow the "castle doctrine", under which people have no duty to retreat when they are attacked in their homes, or (in some places) in their vehicles or workplaces. The castle doctrine and "stand-your-ground" laws provide legal defenses to persons who have been charged with various use-of-force crimes against persons, such as murder, manslaughter, aggravated assault, and illegal discharge or brandishing of weapons, as well as attempts to commit such crimes.
Whether a jurisdiction follows stand-your-ground or duty-to-retreat is just one element of its self-defense laws.  Different jurisdictions allow deadly force against different crimes. All American states allow it against prior deadly force, great bodily injury, and likely kidnapping or rape; some also allow it against threat of robbery and burglary.
A 2020 RAND Corporation review of existing research concluded: "There is supportive evidence that stand-your-ground laws are associated with increases in firearm homicides and moderate evidence that they increase the total number of homicides."
story:
It was a hot summer evening when John, a 35-year-old software engineer, was walking home from the grocery store through a dark alley. As he approached his apartment, he noticed a group of teenagers, who looked suspicious, lingering around his building's entrance. One of them, seemingly high on something, approached John, asking him for money. When John refused, the teenager's demeanor turned aggressive.

The group began to close in on John, and one of them grabbed his phone. John felt threatened and realized he needed to defend himself. In Florida, where he lived, law enforcement had emphasized the importance of stand-your-ground laws, which meant John didn't have to retreat before using deadly force.

As the teenagers continued to close in, John's training kicked in, and he drew his concealed pistol. The teenagers, seeing the gun, backed off, but the initial aggressor, now enraged, charged at John. In a split second, John fired, striking the teenager, who fell to the ground. The others fled.

Police arrived, and John, shaken, explained the circumstances. Under Florida's stand-your-ground law, John had exercised his right to self-defense, and the state attorney would likely not pursue charges against him. While some might argue that John could have attempted to flee or called for help, the stand-your-ground law ensured that, provided John was in a lawful place, he did not have to abandon his right to defend himself.

This incident highlights the key principle of stand-your-ground law: when faced with an imminent threat, a person can use deadly force to protect themselves, without the duty to retreat or attempt to escape the danger.

definition:
In tort law, the standard of care is the only degree of prudence and caution required of an individual who is under a duty of care.
The requirements of the standard are closely dependent on circumstances. Whether the standard of care has been breached is determined by the trier of fact, and is usually phrased in terms of the reasonable person; this is sometimes labeled as the "reasonable physician standard". It was famously described in Vaughn v. Menlove (1837) as whether the individual "proceed[ed] with such reasonable caution as a prudent man would have exercised under such circumstances".
story:
Dr. Smith, a respected gynecologist, had been caring for a patient named Sarah for several months. Sarah was a high-risk pregnancy, and Dr. Smith had advised her to attend regular check-ups and screenings to monitor the baby's health. However, during one of their appointments, Dr. Smith was running late due to a unexpected emergency in the emergency room. As a result, Sarah's appointment was delayed by 30 minutes.

The delay caused Sarah to arrive late for her next scheduled appointment, which was intended to detect a critical congenital anomaly in the baby. However, the test was only offered during a narrow window of time, and by the time Sarah arrived, it was too late. The anomaly was not detected, and the baby was born with a severe condition that required immediate surgery.

In her lawsuit against Dr. Smith, Sarah argued that the doctor had breach the standard of care by failing to schedule a backup appointment or communicate with her in a timely manner. The court had to determine whether Dr. Smith had acted with the same degree of prudence and caution as a reasonable physician in similar circumstances.

In this case, the court found that Dr. Smith had breached the standard of care by being late and not taking necessary precautions to accommodate Sarah's busy schedule. A reasonable physician would have planned for unexpected situations and ensured that Sarah received timely care. Ultimately, the court held Dr. Smith liable for the damages caused by his breach of the standard of care.

definition:
In law, standing or locus standi is a condition that a party seeking a legal remedy must show they have, by demonstrating to the court, sufficient connection to and harm from the law or action challenged to support that party's participation in the case. A party has standing in the following situations:

The party is directly subject to an adverse effect by the statute or action in question, and the harm suffered will continue unless the court grants relief in the form of damages or a finding that the law either does not apply to the party or that the law is void or can be nullified. In informal terms, a party must have something to lose. The party has standing because they will be directly harmed by the conditions for which they are asking the court for relief.
The party is not directly harmed by the conditions for which they are petitioning the court for relief but asks for it because the harm involved has some reasonable relation to their situation, and the continued existence of the harm may affect others who might not be able to ask a court for relief. In the United States, this is grounds for asking for a law to be struck down for violating the First Amendment to the Constitution of the United States, because, even though the plaintiff might not be directly affected, the law might adversely affect others, because they might not know when they were violating it. This is known as the "chilling effects" doctrine.
The party is granted automatic standing by act of law. For example, under some environmental laws in the United States, a party may sue someone causing pollution to certain waterways without a federal permit, even if the party suing is not harmed by the pollution being generated. The law allows the plaintiff to receive attorney's fees from the defendant if they substantially prevail in the action. In some U.S. states, a person who believes a book, film, or other work of art is obscene may sue in their own name to have the work banned directly without having to ask a district attorney to do so.
In the United States, a person may not bring a suit challenging the constitutionality of a law unless they can demonstrate that they are or will "imminently" be harmed by the law. Otherwise, the court will rule that the plaintiff lacks standing to bring the suit and will dismiss it without considering the merits of the claim of unconstitutionality.
story:
As a local business owner, Emily had always been passionate about keeping her community clean and green. She took pride in maintaining a spotless storefront and hosting community events on her property. Recently, her landlord, Mr. Johnson, had decided to neighboring land for a massive condo development. Emily was devastated by the news, knowing that the project would bring traffic, noise, and pollution to the area.

Emily wanted to take legal action against the project, but she was concerned about standing. She didn't own the neighboring land, and she wasn't directly affected by the project, but she was definitely going to be affected indirectly. The increased noise and pollution would disrupt her business, and the changed traffic patterns would make it harder for her customers to get to her store.

Emily's lawyer advised her that she did have standing to sue, as the harm caused by the project had a reasonable relation to her situation. She wasn't just looking out for herself, but for the overall well-being of her community. The lawyer added that Emily's concerns about the environment and public health were legitimate and gave her the right to ask the court to stop the project.

Feeling empowered, Emily decided to take her case to court. She argued that the project violated environmental regulations and neglected the community's need for green spaces. In the end, the court agreed, and the project was halted. Emily's determination and willingness to take a stand (pardon the pun) paved the way for a cleaner, healthier environment for her community.

definition: In United States constitutional law, state action is an action by a person who is acting on behalf of a governmental body, and is therefore subject to limitations imposed on government by the United States Constitution, including the First, Fifth, and Fourteenth Amendments, which prohibit the federal and state governments from violating certain rights and freedoms.
story:
Here's a short story:

Mayra was a 20-year-old college student living in a small town with a predominantly Spanish-speaking community. She was an avid participant in student government on campus and had always been passionate about advocating for students' rights and interests.

As a college town, the town council, responsible for making decisions that impacted local students, operated under a provision that allowed them to enforce town ordinances with the help of police officers from the local law enforcement agency. One of these ordinances banned public speaking on campus without a permit, supposedly to maintain order.

During an anti-budget-cut protest, Mayra, frustrated with a proposed tuition hike, decided to use a megaphone to express her thoughts without a permit. Local police officers showed up and arrested Mayra for violating the ordinance. Unbeknownst to Mayra, the police officers were wearing civilian clothes and badges that looked very similar to those of regular officers. Mayra was booked and charged with disorderly conduct.

Responding to the humiliation and consternation, Mayra asked to see her arrest records. Discovering the officer's real intent - to enforce a town ordinance under apparent color of authority, Mayra brought suit, arguing the enforcement of the ban on public speech to be an unconstitutional infringement of her First Amendment rights as protected by the U.S. Constitution.

This scenario illustrates the concept of a state actor: the police officer wears the badge of the local law enforcement agency, seemingly acting with the same powers they would have if the order had come directly from the local government. However, because they leverage the apparent authority of this employment, they become accountable to the constitutional limitations that are set for the government.

definition: The step transaction doctrine is a judicial doctrine in the United States that combines a series of formally separate steps, resulting in tax treatment as a single integrated event. The doctrine is often used in combination with other doctrines, such as substance over form. The doctrine is applied to prevent tax abuse, such as tax shelters or bailing assets out of a corporation. The step transaction doctrine originated from a common law principle in Gregory v. Helvering, 293 U.S. 465 (1935), which allowed the court to recharacterize a tax-motivated transaction.
story:
Here's a story that illustrates the step transaction doctrine:

Meet Emma, a successful entrepreneur who owns a small bakery. She's been using the company to fund her passion for making artisanal bread. Emma has been thinking of scaling up her business and is considering buying a larger building to expand her operations.

Emma approaches her lawyer, David, seeking advice on how to acquire the new property. David suggests that Emma buy the building directly, but warns her that the tax implications might not be ideal. Instead, David proposes a creative solution: Emma will form a new corporation, "Breadwinner Inc.," and transfer her ownership stake in the bakery to it. Then, Breadwinner Inc. will borrow money from a bank to purchase the new building.

Emma is delighted by the idea, as she'll only pay taxes on the interest she owes on the loan, rather than the full value of the building. David advises Emma to ensure that the loan is treated as a legitimate debt, so she sets up a promissory note and has the bank record a lien on the property.

However, the IRS audits Emma's taxes and determines that the entire transaction was designed solely to avoid taxes. They argue that the series of steps – forming the new corporation, transferring the bakery, and borrowing money – were merely a disguised attempt to avoid paying taxes. The court agrees, and the step transaction doctrine is applied, treating the entire transaction as a single, integrated event. This means Emma is required to pay taxes on the full value of the building, rather than just the loan interest.

definition:
Stopping the clock is a controversial practice in American and Canadian parliamentary procedure in which a legislature literally or notionally stops the clock (or moves the hands backwards), usually for the purpose of meeting a constitutional or statutory deadline. Riddick's Rules of Procedure notes, "The official clock is stopped by agreement of the 'powers that be' without any motion or announcement one minute before the designated hour." Sometimes it is done to allow more time for lobbying or deal-making to obtain the necessary votes for one side to prevail on a measure. Some legislatures actually stop the clock, and others simply use it as a metaphor for continuing business after a time deadline has passed. Stopping the clock is also sometimes done for ceremonial purposes to ensure that both houses of a bicameral legislature adjourn simultaneously.
The glossary of the Alabama State Legislature notes that the plug to the electric clock in the Senate or House chamber is sometimes pulled to allow the staff to complete the massive paper work required before sine die adjournment. 
Sometimes a legislature will even take a recess while the clock is stopped and then resume its work. The New York Legislature used to literally stop the clock at midnight on April 1 in order to pass the budget by the constitutional deadline, but eventually ended the practice and began simply disregarding the requirement. In 2004, it finally moved the deadline back to May 1. 
In a debate of the Legislative Assembly of Saskatchewan, it was noted that stopping the clock is done by tradition and with unanimous consent, when the Opposition agrees with the Government that valuable business can be done by extending the hours. In contrast, the speaker of the Illinois Legislature unilaterally stopped the clock at midnight on the last day of its session on June 30, 1988, to allow further debate before approving money to replace Comiskey Park, a decision that ultimately passed by one vote. Had this maneuver not been done, the White Sox presumably would have moved to Florida. Stadium consultant Marc Ganis noted, "As the clock struck down in St. Petersburg, they started popping champagne corks and didn't realize that the speaker of the house can literally stop the clock in Illinois. At the stroke of midnight, we got to 60 votes."
story:
It was June 30th, the last day of the legislative session in Sacramento, California. The House of Representatives was in a heated debate over a bill to build a new highway system. With only 30 minutes left before the constitutional deadline, the speaker of the House, Rachel Lee, stood up and suggested stopping the clock to allow more time for negotiations. After some deliberation, both sides agreed, and the chamber's clock was brought to a standstill.

As the clock froze at 11:30 PM, the room erupted into a flurry of lobbying and horse-trading. The supporters of the bill huddled with the opponents, trying to convince them to switch their votes. Meanwhile, the House staff scrambled to complete the paperwork necessary for the bill's passage.

The clock remained stopped as the representatives worked tirelessly to find a compromise. Finally, after several hours of intense negotiations, a deal was reached. The bill was passed, and the House adjourned without having stopped the clock formally, but it was clear what had happened - the clock had been effectively stopped to allow for the necessary time to secure the votes.

The debate team patted themselves on the back, grateful that the last-minute agreement had been reached and the bill would be put into effect. But in the back room, Rachel whispered to her aide, "We couldn't have done it without stopping the clock. It was the only way we were going to get the votes." The world outside remained oblivious to the hush-hush maneuver, but in the legislative world of Sacramento, stopping the clock was a well-understood convention that allowed business to be done.

definition:
Subsidiarity is a principle of social organization that holds that social and political issues should be dealt with at the most immediate or local level that is consistent with their resolution. The Oxford English Dictionary defines subsidiarity as "the principle that a central authority should have a subsidiary function, performing only those tasks which cannot be performed at a more local level". The concept is applicable in the fields of government, political science, neuropsychology, cybernetics, management and in military command (mission command). The OED adds that the term "subsidiarity" in English follows the early German usage of "Subsidiarität". More distantly, it is derived from the Latin verb subsidio (to aid or help), and the related noun subsidium (aid or assistance).
The development of the concept of subsidiarity has roots in the natural law philosophy of Thomas Aquinas and was mediated by the social scientific theories of Luigi Taparelli, SJ, in his 1840–43 natural law treatise on the human person in society. In that work, Taparelli established the criteria of just social order, which he referred to as "hypotactical right" and which came to be termed subsidiarity following German influences.
Another origin of the concept is in the writings of Calvinist law-philosopher Johannes Althaus who used the word "subsidia" in 1603. As a principle of just social order, it became one of the pillars of modern Catholic social teaching. Subsidiarity is a general principle of European Union law. In the United States of America, Article VI, Paragraph 2 of the constitution of the United States is known as the Supremacy Clause. This establishes that the federal constitution, and federal law generally, take precedence over state laws, and even state constitutions. The principle of States' Rights is sometimes interpreted as being established by the Tenth Amendment, which says that "The powers not delegated to the United States by the Constitution, nor prohibited by it to the States, are reserved to the States respectively, or to the people."
story:
Meet Emily, a local business owner in a small town. She owns a popular bakery that employs several people in the community. The town has a vibrant downtown area where many local shops and restaurants are located.

One day, Emily notices that a homeless individual often visits the shops in the area, causing a nuisance and disrupting the businesses. The occasional encounters are stressful, and the owners feel that something needs to be done. Emily decides to take the initiative and proposes to the other local business owners a plan to create a local organization to help the homeless individual.

The plan is to provide basic necessities like food, clothing, and shelter to the individual, and also connect them with local authorities and social services. The goal is to create a sense of community and social responsibility among the local businesses.

The other business owners are impressed with Emily's proposal and decide to support her initiative. They work together to gather resources, volunteer their time, and coordinate efforts. The local government, however, has a separate program in place to address homelessness, but it focuses on long-term solutions and may take time to take effect.

In this scenario, the principle of subsidiarity is applied. The local community, comprising Emily and the other business owners, deals with the issue of homelessness at the most immediate level, providing temporary support and assistance to the individual. The local government's program for homelessness takes a more comprehensive approach, dealing with the issue at a higher level and providing long-term solutions. This approach acknowledges that smaller, local efforts can have a significant impact, while also recognizing that larger, more systemic issues may require a broader, more comprehensive response.

definition: Substance over form is an accounting principle used "to ensure that financial statements give a complete, relevant, and accurate picture of transactions and events". If an entity practices the 'substance over form' concept, then the financial statements will convey the overall financial reality of the entity (economic substance), rather than simply reporting the legal record of transactions (form). In accounting for business transactions and other events, the measurement and reporting is for the economic impact of an event, instead of its legal form. Substance over form is critical for reliable financial reporting. It is particularly relevant in cases of revenue recognition, sale and purchase agreements, etc. The key point of the concept is that a transaction should not be recorded in such a manner as to hide the true intent of the transaction, which would mislead the readers of a company's financial statements.
story:
Sarah, a small business owner, entered into an agreement with her cousin, Alex, to store her inventory in his warehouse for a fee. On the surface, the agreement looked like a typical rental agreement, with a lease term, rent, and security deposit. However, the reality was different. Sarah would only keep the inventory in Alex's warehouse for a short period, usually a few days, and then re-sell it. Alex would then re-rent the same space to other businesses. The agreement was structured this way because Alex's warehouse was strategically located, making it easier for Sarah to sell her products quickly.

One day, an auditor reviewed Sarah's financial statements and noticed that the rental income from Alex's warehouse was recorded as a normal rental income. The auditor questioned why Sarah was recording the income as rental income, when in essence, she was essentially flipping the inventory. The auditor argued that the true substance of the transaction was not the rental income, but rather the sale of the inventory.

After reviewing the facts, Sarah realized that the auditor was correct. She was recording the rental income as a way to disguise the real transaction, which was the sale of inventory. To accurately reflect the financial reality of the transaction, Sarah changed the accounting treatment to record the income as the sale of inventory, rather than rental income. By doing so, she ensured that her financial statements accurately reflected the true intent of the transaction, rather than just its legal form. This is an example of the substance over form principle, where the focus is on the economic reality of the transaction, rather than just its legal representation.

definition: In law, the substantial certainty doctrine is the assumption of intent even if the actor did not intend the result, but knew with substantial certainty the effect would occur as a result of his action. The doctrine can be used by courts as a test to determine whether or not a defendant committed a tort. For example, in Garratt v. Dailey (1955), the Washington Supreme Court remanded a case back to the lower courts to determine whether or not the five year-old defendant "knew with substantial certainty that the plaintiff would attempt to sit down where the chair which he moved had been."
story:
Sarah, a construction worker, was tasked with moving a heavy crate in a warehouse. She knew that the crate was prone to tipping over and causing harm, but she didn't want to waste time finding a safer way to move it. In a hurry, she quickly pushed the crate without securing it properly, knowing with substantial certainty that someone would likely walk into the path of the falling crate.

To her dismay, a coworker, Alex, was indeed walking in that direction. As the crate fell, Sarah shouted a warning, but it was too late. Alex was hit and suffered serious injuries.
